monogr.title: Fidessa, more chaste then kinde. By B. Griffin, gent
monogr.author: Griffin, B., gent

div.head: TO THE MOST KINDE AND VERTVous gentleman, M. VVilliam Essex of Lamebourne, in the Countie of Barke Esquire.
div.p:
SIr, it may seeme strange that I should be thus far bold to make choyce of your selfe, a patron of so slender a work, (especially being so little knowne vnto you as I am:) but howsoeuer, I protest what is done, proceedeth from the vnfained loue I beare vnto you, your owne demerit,
your friendes hope, & the good reporte of all men. All which, are liuely-witnesses of your loue to the Muses, your grace with fortune, & your fame with the worlde, quickened in your birth, increased in your trauailes, and liuing after death. Daigne (sweete sir) to pardon the matter, iudge fauorably of the manner, and accept both: so shall I euer rest yours in all dewtifull affection.
